description: Explore the history and future of human and robotic space exploration

slides.title: Welcome to Space Exploration
slides.content:
# Introduction to Space Exploration

Welcome to **Space Exploration** - humanity's journey to the stars!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Early Space Age** - Sputnik to Apollo
- **Space Stations** - Living in space
- **Robotic Exploration** - Probes and rovers
- **Current Missions** - Active exploration
- **Future Plans** - Moon, Mars, and beyond

> **Fun Fact:** Voyager 1 is the most distant human-made object, over 15 billion miles away!

slides.title: The Space Race
slides.content:
# The Space Race (1957-1975)

## Key Milestones:

| Year | Event | Nation |
|------|-------|--------|
| 1957 | Sputnik 1 (first satellite) | USSR |
| 1961 | First human in space (Gagarin) | USSR |
| 1961 | First American in space (Shepard) | USA |
| 1963 | First woman in space (Tereshkova) | USSR |
| 1965 | First spacewalk | USSR |
| 1969 | First Moon landing (Apollo 11) | USA |
| 1975 | Apollo-Soyuz (end of rivalry) | Joint |

## Motivations:
- Cold War competition
- National prestige
- Technology development

slides.title: Apollo Program
slides.content:
# Apollo Program

## Goal:
Land humans on Moon and return safely.

## Key Missions:

| Mission | Achievement |
|---------|-------------|
| Apollo 1 | Fire tragedy (1967) |
| Apollo 8 | First lunar orbit |
| Apollo 11 | First landing (July 20, 1969) |
| Apollo 13 | Survived explosion |
| Apollo 17 | Last Moon mission (1972) |

## Apollo 11 Crew:
- Neil Armstrong (commander)
- Buzz Aldrin (lunar module pilot)
- Michael Collins (command module pilot)

## Legacy:
- 12 astronauts walked on Moon
- 842 lbs of lunar samples returned

slides.title: Space Shuttle Era
slides.content:
# Space Shuttle (1981-2011)

## Design:
- Reusable orbiter
- External tank (discarded)
- Solid rocket boosters

## Missions:
- 135 total flights
- ISS construction
- Hubble deployment and repairs
- Spacelab missions

## Fleet:
- Columbia (lost 2003)
- Challenger (lost 1986)
- Discovery
- Atlantis
- Endeavour

## Achievements:
- First reusable spacecraft
- Carried diverse crews
- Built International Space Station

slides.title: International Space Station
slides.content:
# International Space Station (ISS)

## Quick Facts:
- Launched: 1998 (first module)
- Size: Football field length
- Orbit: ~400 km altitude
- Crew: 6-7 astronauts

## Partners:
- NASA (USA)
- Roscosmos (Russia)
- ESA (Europe)
- JAXA (Japan)
- CSA (Canada)

## Science:
- Microgravity research
- Biology, materials, physics
- Earth observation

## Future:
- Operating until 2030+
- Commercial stations planned

slides.title: Robotic Mars Exploration
slides.content:
# Mars Exploration

## Rovers:

| Rover | Years | Key Finding |
|-------|-------|-------------|
| Sojourner | 1997 | Proof of concept |
| Spirit | 2004-2010 | Ancient water evidence |
| Opportunity | 2004-2018 | 28 miles traveled! |
| Curiosity | 2012-present | Habitable conditions |
| Perseverance | 2021-present | Collects samples |

## Orbiters:
- Mars Odyssey
- Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter
- MAVEN

## Landers:
- InSight (seismology)
- Phoenix (polar ice)

## Ingenuity:
- First helicopter on another planet

slides.title: Outer Solar System Exploration
slides.content:
# Outer Solar System Missions

## Pioneer:
- Pioneer 10 & 11 (1970s)
- First to Jupiter, Saturn
- Carry plaques for aliens

## Voyager:
- Voyager 1 & 2 (1977)
- Grand Tour of outer planets
- Still transmitting!
- Interstellar space reached

## Cassini-Huygens:
- Saturn orbiter (2004-2017)
- Huygens landed on Titan
- Discovered Enceladus geysers

## Juno:
- Jupiter orbiter (2016-present)
- Studies interior and atmosphere

## New Horizons:
- Pluto flyby (2015)
- Arrokoth flyby (2019)

slides.title: Space Telescopes
slides.content:
# Space Telescopes

## Major Telescopes:

| Telescope | Wavelength | Launch |
|-----------|-----------|--------|
| Hubble | Visible, UV, near-IR | 1990 |
| Chandra | X-ray | 1999 |
| Spitzer | Infrared | 2003 |
| Kepler/TESS | Visible | 2009/2018 |
| JWST | Infrared | 2021 |

## James Webb Space Telescope:
- Largest space telescope
- 6.5 meter mirror
- Infrared observations
- L2 Lagrange point
- First images: July 2022

slides.title: Current Commercial Spaceflight
slides.content:
# Commercial Spaceflight

## SpaceX:
- Falcon 9 (reusable)
- Falcon Heavy
- Dragon (crew and cargo)
- Starship (development)

## Blue Origin:
- New Shepard (suborbital tourism)
- New Glenn (heavy lift)

## Boeing:
- Starliner (crew capsule)

## Others:
- Rocket Lab
- Virgin Galactic
- Sierra Space

## Achievements:
- Reusable rockets (SpaceX)
- Commercial ISS resupply
- Private astronaut missions

slides.title: Artemis Program
slides.content:
# Artemis Program

## Goal:
Return humans to Moon, establish sustainable presence.

## Key Elements:
- SLS rocket (heavy lift)
- Orion capsule
- Gateway (lunar station)
- Human Landing System

## Timeline:
- Artemis I: Uncrewed test (2022)
- Artemis II: Crewed lunar flyby
- Artemis III: First woman on Moon

## Partners:
- NASA + international partners
- Commercial: SpaceX HLS

## Goals:
- First woman on Moon
- First person of color on Moon
- Prepare for Mars missions

slides.quizQuestion: The Artemis program aims to return humans to:

slides.title: Mars - The Next Frontier
slides.content:
# Human Mars Exploration

## Challenges:
- 6-9 month journey
- Radiation exposure
- Life support
- Landing on thin atmosphere
- Communication delay (4-24 min)

## Timeline Estimates:
- 2030s-2040s for first humans

## Key Players:
- NASA (Moon to Mars)
- SpaceX (Starship)
- China (planned missions)

## Requirements:
- Reliable heavy-lift rockets
- In-situ resource utilization
- Long-duration life support
- Radiation shielding

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Space Exploration Summary

## History:
| Era | Highlight |
|-----|----------|
| 1960s | Moon race |
| 1970s | Skylab, Voyager |
| 1980s-2000s | Shuttle, ISS |
| 2010s-present | Commercial, JWST |

## Current Focus:
- ISS operations
- Mars rovers (Perseverance)
- JWST discoveries
- Artemis returning to Moon

## Future:
- Sustainable lunar presence
- Human Mars missions
- Commercial space growth

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Space Exploration!
